summary: This is an FBI internal request form from the Miami Division to the Document Conversion Laboratory (DocLab) and Special Technologies and Applications Office (STAG) to scan and process telephone records related to the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez. The document reveals Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager, possessed an address book believed to contain names of additional underage victims and attempted to sell it.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein; subject of obstruction of justice case
persons.context: Subject of the FBI's obstruction of justice investigation. He was Epstein's house manager and came into possession of an address book containing names and numbers of potential additional underage victims, which he attempted to sell.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: Referenced as the individual to whom Alfredo Rodriguez was employed. He is the central figure in the child prostitution case from which the address book in Rodriguez's possession originated.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Miami Division opens obstruction case against Rodriguez
events.description: The FBI's Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: FBI requests document conversion for telephone records
events.description: The FBI Miami Division submits a formal request to the Document Conversion Laboratory to scan and process telephone records related to the Alfredo Rodriguez obstruction case for incorporation into the Telephone Application (TA) database.

locations: Winchester, Virginia 22602 (Location of the FBI's Document Conversion Laboratory)
Miami (Location of the FBI division handling the case)
keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager and butler, was the subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case opened in October 2009.
Rodriguez came into possession of an address book belonging to Epstein that contained names and telephone numbers of what were believed to be additional, previously unknown underage victims.
Rodriguez attempted to sell the address book rather than turn it over to law enforcement or attorneys in response to federal subpoenas.
The FBI was processing telephone records obtained from the address book, believed to belong to Epstein, his associates, or potential underage victims.
This document is an internal FBI request for technical assistance to scan and digitize these telephone records for investigative analysis.
